metadata.title: Deployment of Web App + ML Model + APIs — Tutorial | by André Sionek | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Deployment of Web App + ML Model + APIs — Tutorial
metadata.description: What is the point of creating a ML model if you don’t put it into production? Calculating model’s metrics and tuning it to better performance is NOT the end of a data scientist job. You can do much…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Here you can access the working app that we are developing at this tutorial. Play with it as you like.
check out how the model we are using here was developed.
Towards Data Science post, by Ben Weber
you can just clone it from my github

all_paragraphs: What is the point of creating a ML model if you don’t put it into production? Calculating model’s metrics and tuning it to better performance is NOT the end of a data scientist job. You can do much more than that. In fact, deploying a scalable model is much easier than it looks like. And knowing how to do it, certainly will add great value to your resume, because most data scientists don’t go that far. You can think of this tutorial as the first step into becoming a data science unicorn.

We will deploy a Logistic Regression model in AWS Lambda and then create API endpoints with API Gateway. With that done you have a scalable model that works as a service, you just do a simple POST request and it returns the prediction back to you.
Then we will build a Flask App with HTML form to get some answers to feed our model. The app makes a request to our API, redirect the user to another page and exhibits the model prediction on it.
Here you can access the working app that we are developing at this tutorial. Play with it as you like.

The main objective of this article is not to develop a model, but you are free to check out how the model we are using here was developed. It is a simple Logistic Regression Model. To deploy it we have basically two options:

I’m choosing the second option because I want the model to be transparent to anyone. It should be clear what the coefficients are and how the score is calculated. A serialized model wouldn’t let us see that in detail.
You’ll find instructions on how to deploy a serialized model to AWS Lambda on this Towards Data Science post, by Ben Weber.
A Logistic Regression model can be written like this:

We trained our model and got all coefficient’s values. So it’s just a matter of writing that equation manually: summing all coefficients and the intercept. Then to get scores (the probability) between 0 and 1 we do:
Log in into your AWS console, go to IAM and create a role that has at least those permissions policies attached:
Then you can go to Lambda and click into “Create function”. Now we will define the basic configuration of our function.
Now you go down to function code and add the following to the lambda function that was already created:

The function receives a json as the event argument and treat it to the right format. Next we calculate the score with our helper function that we will define below, then we build a response and return it. Simple as that.
Now we will create some helper functions. Go to File > New From Template > Python File:
Add the following code and save it as normalizer.py:
Create a new Python file, name it pre_treatment.py:
Finally we will add a function that calculates the score. Note that the model coefficients are hardcoded here. Name it scorer.py.
Done! Now let’s create an API for our model. At Designer > Add triggers, click on API Gateway.

Click on configuration required, choose create a new API, and then save your lambda function. If you come back to the API Gateway you should see an endpoint available. That’s the one you are using to access your API.
To test your API, just send a POST request to the endpoint like the one below (replace the url by the one you just created):
You should expect to get the calculated score as a response. Something like this:
Great! We just created a scalable service that runs our model given an input. Now we build a web app that sends a request to our service and expects the score as answer.
The full project has more functions, check it out here:
Create a project with the following folder structure (you can just clone it from my github).
There are two HTML pages (index.html and score.html) stored inside templates folder. All css, images and js are inside static folder. We are interested here in the application.py:
To deploy our app to beanstalk its quite simple as well.
To do additional deploys and updates:
The full Flask project is available here:

This was a tutorial to deploying a ML model as a service, creating an API, and finally a building web application using Flask that make requests to our model’s API. I know this tutorial is probably oversimplified, but you’ll find plenty of additional detailed material on each topic covered here with a simple online search. The idea was just to show that it’s possible and it’s not complicated!
I hope this article helps you on finding your way into being a more valuable data scientist!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
I write about data and software engineering, career and everything in between!
